title: Sharing is Caring
story: Bunny was playing with their favorite red ball in the park. Along came Fox, who wanted to play with the ball too. Bunny felt sad because they didn't want to share their special ball. What should Bunny do?
imagePrompt: A cute bunny holding a red ball, with a friendly fox nearby in a sunny park

choices.text: Share the ball and take turns playing
choices.explanation: Great choice! Sharing helps us make friends and have more fun together. When we share, everyone feels happy!

choices.text: Run away with the ball
choices.explanation: Running away might make Fox feel sad. Let's think about how we can both have fun together!

choices.text: Say 'maybe later' and keep playing alone
choices.explanation: It's okay to want to play alone sometimes, but sharing can make playtime even more fun! Maybe you could play together for a little while?

choices.text: Ask Fox to bring their own ball
choices.explanation: That's a creative idea! But right now, Fox wants to play with you. Sharing your ball could be a great way to make a new friend!

endingMessage: You did a wonderful job thinking about sharing! When we share our toys, we make friends and create happy memories together. Remember, sharing makes playtime more fun for everyone! üåü

title: Dark Night, Bright Heart
story: It was bedtime and Bear's room was very dark. Bear felt scared because they couldn't see anything. The shadows on the wall looked like scary monsters. What should Bear do?
imagePrompt: A small bear in a cozy bedroom at night, with soft shadows and a nightlight nearby

choices.text: Ask a grown-up for a nightlight or to leave the door open
choices.explanation: Excellent idea! Asking for help when we're scared is very brave. A nightlight or open door can make the dark feel safer!

choices.text: Stay awake all night
choices.explanation: Staying awake all night would make Bear very tired. It's better to find a way to feel safe so we can rest!

choices.text: Hide under the covers
choices.explanation: Hiding can feel safe for a moment, but talking to a grown-up about our fears helps us feel better for the whole night!

choices.text: Pretend to be asleep
choices.explanation: Pretending won't make the scary feelings go away. It's better to tell someone how we feel so they can help us!

endingMessage: You're so brave! It's okay to feel scared sometimes. Talking to grown-ups about our fears helps us find ways to feel safe and peaceful. Sweet dreams! üåô

title: Where Did It Go?
story: Puppy couldn't find their favorite stuffed animal, Mr. Snuggles. They looked in their room, the living room, and even the backyard, but Mr. Snuggles was nowhere to be found. Puppy felt worried and sad. What should Puppy do?
imagePrompt: A worried puppy looking around a messy room, searching for a lost stuffed animal

choices.text: Ask a grown-up to help search and check the last place they remember having it
choices.explanation: Great thinking! Asking for help and retracing our steps is the best way to find lost things. Grown-ups can help us look in places we might forget!

choices.text: Cry and give up looking
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel sad, but giving up means we might never find Mr. Snuggles! Let's try asking for help instead!

choices.text: Keep looking alone in the same places
choices.explanation: It's good to keep trying! But sometimes asking for help or thinking about new places to look can help us find things faster!

choices.text: Buy a new toy instead
choices.explanation: A new toy might be fun, but Mr. Snuggles is special! Let's try to find the original one first - it might be in a surprising place!

endingMessage: You showed great problem-solving skills! When we lose something important, asking for help and thinking carefully about where we last saw it can help us find it. Don't give up! üîç

title: Time for Bed
story: Kitten had been playing all day and now it was bedtime. Kitten felt very tired but didn't want to stop playing. They wanted to stay up and have more fun. What should Kitten do?
imagePrompt: A sleepy kitten yawning, with toys scattered around and a cozy bed in the background

choices.text: Follow the bedtime routine: brush teeth, put on pajamas, read a story, then sleep
choices.explanation: Perfect! Following a bedtime routine helps our bodies and minds get ready for sleep. We'll have more energy for fun tomorrow!

choices.text: Keep playing until they fall asleep on the floor
choices.explanation: Sleeping on the floor isn't as comfortable as a bed! A good bedtime routine helps us sleep better and feel rested!

choices.text: Ask to stay up just 10 more minutes
choices.explanation: It's okay to ask, but our bodies need rest to grow and stay healthy. A good night's sleep helps us have more fun tomorrow!

choices.text: Hide so no one can find them
choices.explanation: Hiding won't help us feel less tired! It's better to talk about our feelings and follow our bedtime routine together!

endingMessage: You made a smart choice! Sleep is important for growing bodies and happy days. When we get good rest, we wake up ready for new adventures! Good night! üåô

title: First Day Adventure
story: Duckling was starting at a new school tomorrow. They had never been to school before and didn't know anyone. Duckling felt nervous about meeting new friends and learning new things. What should Duckling do?
imagePrompt: A small duckling looking at a school building, feeling nervous but curious

choices.text: Talk to a grown-up about feelings, pack a favorite toy, and remember that everyone feels nervous on the first day
choices.explanation: Wonderful! Talking about our feelings and bringing something familiar can help us feel braver. Remember, everyone feels nervous on the first day - you're not alone!

choices.text: Pretend to be sick so they don't have to go
choices.explanation: Pretending to be sick won't make the nervous feelings go away. It's better to talk about how we feel and find ways to feel braver!

choices.text: Stay quiet and hope no one notices them
choices.explanation: It's okay to be quiet, but school is a place to make friends and learn! Maybe you could try saying hello to one person - they might be nervous too!

choices.text: Bring lots of toys to share
choices.explanation: Sharing is nice, but the most important thing is to be yourself and be kind. Your new friends will like you for who you are!

endingMessage: You're so brave! Starting something new can feel scary, but it's also exciting! Remember, everyone at school is learning and making friends too. You've got this! üéí

title: Playground Pals
story: Squirrel was at the playground and saw other animals playing together. Squirrel wanted to join them but felt shy and didn't know how to ask. Squirrel felt lonely watching everyone else have fun. What should Squirrel do?
imagePrompt: A squirrel watching other animals play together on a playground, looking shy and hopeful

choices.text: Walk over, smile, and say 'Can I play too?'
choices.explanation: Excellent! Being friendly and asking to join is the best way to make new friends. Most kids love when others want to play with them!

choices.text: Go home because no one wants to play with them
choices.explanation: Don't give up! The other animals probably don't know you want to play. Asking them is the first step to making friends!

choices.text: Wait and hope someone invites them
choices.explanation: Waiting is okay, but sometimes we need to be brave and ask! Most kids are happy to include new friends in their games!

choices.text: Play alone and ignore everyone
choices.explanation: Playing alone can be fun, but if you want to play with others, it's better to ask! You might be surprised how welcoming they are!

endingMessage: You showed great courage! Making friends can feel scary, but being friendly and asking to join in is how friendships begin. You're a wonderful friend! üéà

title: Test Day Jitters
story: Owl had a big math test tomorrow. They studied hard but still felt worried about forgetting everything. Owl's tummy felt funny and they couldn't sleep. What should Owl do?
imagePrompt: An owl with books and papers, looking worried about an upcoming test

choices.text: Take deep breaths, review notes one more time, get good sleep, and remember they prepared well
choices.explanation: Perfect! Deep breathing helps calm our bodies, and getting rest helps our brains work better. You've prepared - trust yourself!

choices.text: Stay up all night studying more
choices.explanation: Staying up all night makes us too tired to think clearly! Sleep is important for remembering what we learned!

choices.text: Worry about it all night
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel worried, but worrying won't help us do better. Let's try some calming strategies instead!

choices.text: Pretend to be sick to skip the test
choices.explanation: Avoiding the test won't make the worry go away - it will just come back later. It's better to face our fears with good preparation!

endingMessage: You handled that so well! Feeling nervous about tests is normal, and you found healthy ways to cope. Remember, doing your best is what matters most! üìö

title: Left Out
story: Rabbit's best friend Fox was having a birthday party and invited everyone in class except Rabbit. Rabbit felt hurt and confused about why they weren't invited. What should Rabbit do?
imagePrompt: A rabbit looking sad, seeing other animals excited about a party invitation

choices.text: Talk to Fox privately about feelings, ask if there's a reason, and suggest doing something fun together another time
choices.explanation: Great communication! Talking about our feelings in a calm way helps us understand what happened and work through it together!

choices.text: Get angry and stop being friends with Fox
choices.explanation: Getting angry right away might make things worse. It's better to talk about our feelings first and understand what happened!

choices.text: Pretend it doesn't matter and ignore Fox
choices.explanation: It's okay to protect our feelings, but talking about what happened can help us understand and maybe fix the friendship!

choices.text: Have their own party and not invite Fox
choices.explanation: Trying to get back at someone usually makes things worse. It's better to talk about our feelings and try to understand what happened!

endingMessage: You showed emotional maturity! Talking about our feelings when we're hurt is brave and helps us work through problems. Friendships can have bumps, but communication helps! üíô

title: Too Much to Do
story: Beaver had lots of homework: math problems, a book report, and a science project. It all seemed like too much to finish. Beaver felt overwhelmed and didn't know where to start. What should Beaver do?
imagePrompt: A beaver surrounded by books and papers, looking overwhelmed by too much homework

choices.text: Break it into small steps, start with the easiest task, take breaks, and ask for help if needed
choices.explanation: Excellent strategy! Breaking big tasks into smaller pieces makes them feel less scary. Starting with something easy builds confidence!

choices.text: Try to do everything at once
choices.explanation: Doing everything at once can make us feel more overwhelmed! It's better to take things one step at a time!

choices.text: Put it off until the last minute
choices.explanation: Putting things off usually makes us feel more stressed later. Starting early, even with small steps, helps us feel better!

choices.text: Just don't do any of it
choices.explanation: Not doing homework might feel easier now, but it will cause problems later. Let's find a way to make it manageable!

endingMessage: You found a great solution! When things feel too big, breaking them into smaller pieces helps us feel capable and successful. You've got this! üìù

title: Sibling Squabble
story: Chipmunk's little sibling kept interrupting while they were trying to do homework. The sibling wanted to play and wouldn't leave Chipmunk alone. Chipmunk felt frustrated and angry. What should Chipmunk do?
imagePrompt: A chipmunk trying to work while a smaller chipmunk tries to get attention

choices.text: Calmly explain they need quiet time, suggest playing together later, and ask a grown-up for help if needed
choices.explanation: Perfect! Using calm words and setting boundaries helps. Suggesting time together later shows you care about your sibling too!

choices.text: Yell and push the sibling away
choices.explanation: Yelling and pushing can hurt feelings and make things worse. Let's try using calm words instead!

choices.text: Ignore them and hope they go away
choices.explanation: Ignoring might work sometimes, but talking calmly about what you need usually works better and keeps everyone happy!

choices.text: Lock themselves in their room
choices.explanation: Locking doors can be unsafe and doesn't solve the problem. It's better to talk about boundaries with a grown-up's help!

endingMessage: You handled that conflict so well! Setting boundaries calmly and suggesting time together later shows maturity. Siblings can be tricky, but communication helps! üë´

title: Standing Out
story: Penguin loved reading books while all their friends loved playing sports. Sometimes Penguin felt like they didn't fit in because their interests were different. What should Penguin do?
imagePrompt: A penguin reading a book while other animals play sports in the background

choices.text: Embrace their unique interests, find friends who share similar hobbies, and remember that being different is special
choices.explanation: Wonderful! Being different makes you special! It's great to have your own interests, and you can find friends who appreciate what makes you unique!

choices.text: Pretend to like sports just to fit in
choices.explanation: Pretending to be someone else won't make you happy. Being true to yourself helps you find real friends who like you for who you are!

choices.text: Stop reading and only do what friends do
choices.explanation: It's okay to try new things, but you don't have to give up what you love! You can enjoy both your interests and your friends' activities!

choices.text: Avoid all friends completely
choices.explanation: Avoiding friends won't help! You can have your own interests AND be friends with people who have different interests. That's what makes friendships interesting!

endingMessage: You're amazing just as you are! Having different interests makes you unique and interesting. True friends will like you for who you are! üåü

title: Not First This Time
story: Cheetah loved running races and usually won. Today, they came in third place. Cheetah felt disappointed and sad. They thought about giving up running altogether. What should Cheetah do?
imagePrompt: A cheetah looking disappointed after a race, standing on a third-place podium

choices.text: Feel the disappointment, congratulate the winners, practice more, and remember that everyone has off days
choices.explanation: Excellent attitude! It's okay to feel disappointed, but being a good sport and learning from the experience makes you a true champion!

choices.text: Quit running forever
choices.explanation: One race doesn't define you! Everyone has days when things don't go perfectly. Giving up means missing out on future successes!

choices.text: Blame the other runners for winning
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel frustrated, but blaming others won't help us improve. Let's focus on what we can learn and control!

choices.text: Pretend they don't care about running
choices.explanation: Pretending we don't care about something we love won't make us feel better. It's okay to be disappointed and still keep trying!

endingMessage: You showed great sportsmanship! Feeling disappointed is normal, but learning from setbacks and being a good sport makes you a true winner. Keep going! üèÉ

title: Following the Pack
story: Wolf's friends wanted to skip class and go to the park instead. Wolf knew it was wrong but didn't want to be left out or seem uncool. Wolf felt pressured to go along. What should Wolf do?
imagePrompt: A wolf looking conflicted, with friends in the background encouraging them to skip class

choices.text: Politely decline, suggest doing something fun after school instead, and stick to their values
choices.explanation: Excellent decision! Standing up for what you believe in takes courage. True friends will respect your choices, and you can still have fun together in better ways!

choices.text: Go along even though it feels wrong
choices.explanation: Going against our values usually makes us feel worse, not better. It's better to be true to ourselves and find friends who respect our choices!

choices.text: Go but feel guilty about it
choices.explanation: That guilty feeling is telling us something important! When something doesn't feel right, it's usually because it isn't. Trust your instincts!

choices.text: Tell on the friends to get them in trouble
choices.explanation: Tattling to get others in trouble isn't the best approach. It's better to make your own good choice and let others make theirs!

endingMessage: You showed incredible strength! Standing up for your values, even when it's hard, shows true character. You can be a leader by making good choices! üí™

title: New Wings
story: Butterfly used to love dance class, but lately they've been more interested in art. Their dance friends seemed disappointed, and Butterfly felt confused about changing interests. What should Butterfly do?
imagePrompt: A butterfly looking at art supplies while dance shoes sit in the background

choices.text: Talk to friends about the change, explore new interests while keeping old friendships, and remember it's okay to grow and change
choices.explanation: Perfect! It's completely normal for interests to change as we grow. Good friends will support you exploring new things while staying friends!

choices.text: Keep doing dance even though they don't enjoy it anymore
choices.explanation: Doing something you don't enjoy just to please others won't make you happy. It's okay to explore new interests - that's how we grow!

choices.text: Feel guilty about changing
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel a little guilty, but changing interests is a natural part of growing up! You can still be friends with people who have different interests!

choices.text: Stop being friends with dance friends
choices.explanation: You don't have to stop being friends just because your interests changed! Good friendships can include people with different hobbies!

endingMessage: You're growing and discovering who you are! Changing interests is a natural part of growing up. True friends will support you exploring new passions! üé®

title: Growing Apart
story: Dolphin and their best friend Seal had been close for years, but lately they seemed to be growing apart. They had different interests and didn't hang out as much. Dolphin felt sad about the friendship changing. What should Dolphin do?
imagePrompt: Two dolphins swimming in different directions, looking a bit sad

choices.text: Talk openly about the changes, try new activities together, and accept that friendships can evolve while still being meaningful
choices.explanation: Wonderful approach! Friendships do change as we grow, and that's okay. Talking about it and trying new things together can help keep the friendship strong!

choices.text: Get angry and end the friendship completely
choices.explanation: Ending a friendship because it's changing might make us feel worse. It's better to talk about what's happening and see if you can grow together!

choices.text: Pretend everything is the same
choices.explanation: Pretending won't make the changes go away. It's better to acknowledge what's happening and work together to adapt the friendship!

choices.text: Try to force Seal to like the same things
choices.explanation: Trying to change someone else won't work and might push them away. It's better to find new ways to connect that work for both of you!

endingMessage: You handled that with maturity! Friendships do change as we grow, and that's normal. Sometimes friendships evolve, and sometimes we find new ways to stay connected. You're learning important life skills! üíô

title: New Heights
story: Eagle was starting middle school next year. They worried about harder classes, making new friends, getting lost in a bigger school, and having multiple teachers. Eagle felt anxious about all the changes. What should Eagle do?
imagePrompt: An eagle looking at a large school building, feeling nervous about the transition

choices.text: Talk to current teachers, visit the school, connect with other students going there, and remember that everyone feels nervous about transitions
choices.explanation: Excellent preparation! Learning about what to expect and connecting with others helps reduce anxiety. Remember, everyone starting middle school feels nervous - you're not alone!

choices.text: Worry constantly and lose sleep
choices.explanation: Worrying won't help us prepare! It's better to take action - learn about the school, talk to people, and get ready in positive ways!

choices.text: Pretend they're not worried at all
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel worried - that's normal! Acknowledging our feelings and preparing for the change helps us feel more confident!

choices.text: Try to stay in elementary school forever
choices.explanation: We can't avoid growing up, but we can prepare for it! Learning about middle school and getting ready helps us feel more confident about the change!

endingMessage: You're preparing so well! Transitions can feel scary, but you're taking positive steps to get ready. Middle school is a new adventure, and you've got the skills to handle it! üéì

title: Measuring Up
story: Lion worked hard on a science project and got a B+. Their friend got an A+ on the same project. Lion felt like they weren't good enough and compared themselves to their friend. What should Lion do?
imagePrompt: A lion looking at their B+ grade while seeing a friend's A+ grade, feeling disappointed

choices.text: Focus on their own progress, celebrate the B+ as good work, learn from what went well, and remember that everyone has different strengths
choices.explanation: Perfect mindset! Comparing ourselves to others usually makes us feel worse. Focusing on our own growth and celebrating our achievements is much healthier!

choices.text: Feel like a failure and give up on science
choices.explanation: A B+ is good work! One grade doesn't define you. Giving up because someone else did better won't help you grow and learn!

choices.text: Try to copy exactly what the friend did next time
choices.explanation: Learning from others is good, but copying won't help you develop your own skills. Focus on doing your best work in your own way!

choices.text: Stop being friends with the person who got an A+
choices.explanation: Being friends with people who do well can actually help us learn! It's better to focus on our own growth rather than comparing!

endingMessage: You're learning an important lesson! Comparing ourselves to others usually makes us feel worse. Your B+ represents your hard work - that's something to be proud of! Focus on your own journey! üìä

title: Not Getting It
story: Octopus tried to explain to their parents why they wanted to join the robotics club, but their parents didn't seem to understand. They kept suggesting other activities instead. Octopus felt frustrated and misunderstood. What should Octopus do?
imagePrompt: An octopus trying to explain something to adult octopuses, looking frustrated

choices.text: Write down reasons why robotics matters to them, find examples of how it helps learning, and have a calm conversation with parents
choices.explanation: Excellent communication strategy! Sometimes parents need to understand why something matters to us. Preparing your thoughts and having a calm conversation helps!

choices.text: Get angry and storm off
choices.explanation: Getting angry usually makes communication harder. It's better to take time to calm down and then explain your feelings clearly!

choices.text: Give up and not try to explain
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel frustrated, but giving up means your parents might never understand. Try explaining in a different way!

choices.text: Join robotics without telling parents
choices.explanation: Going behind parents' backs usually causes bigger problems. It's better to work on communication and understanding each other!

endingMessage: You showed great communication skills! Feeling misunderstood is frustrating, but finding ways to express yourself clearly helps others understand what matters to you. Keep trying! ü§ñ

title: Waiting My Turn
story: Elephant was waiting in line for the slide at the playground. Other animals kept cutting in front. Elephant had been waiting a long time and felt impatient. They wanted to push ahead too. What should Elephant do?
imagePrompt: An elephant waiting patiently in a line at the playground, looking a bit frustrated

choices.text: Wait patiently, ask a grown-up for help if needed, and remember that waiting is part of playing fairly
choices.explanation: Great patience! Waiting our turn shows respect for others and helps everyone have fun. If someone cuts, asking a grown-up for help is okay!

choices.text: Push ahead of everyone else
choices.explanation: Pushing ahead might make others feel sad or angry. Waiting our turn helps everyone have fun and feel fair!

choices.text: Leave and play something else
choices.explanation: It's okay to play something else if waiting feels too hard, but learning to wait our turn is an important skill!

choices.text: Yell at the other animals
choices.explanation: Yelling usually makes things worse. It's better to wait patiently or ask a grown-up for help if someone isn't being fair!

endingMessage: You showed wonderful patience! Waiting our turn can be hard, but it helps everyone have fun together. Being patient is a superpower! ‚è∞

title: Big Feelings
story: Tiger's tower of blocks fell down right before they finished building it. Tiger felt very angry and wanted to throw the blocks and scream. What should Tiger do?
imagePrompt: A tiger looking angry next to fallen blocks, feeling frustrated

choices.text: Take deep breaths, count to five, and then try building again
choices.explanation: Excellent! Taking deep breaths helps our bodies calm down when we feel angry. Then we can try again with a clear mind!

choices.text: Throw the blocks and scream
choices.explanation: Throwing things can hurt others or break things. It's better to use our words or take deep breaths to calm down!

choices.text: Cry and give up
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel sad when things don't work out, but taking a break and trying again can help us feel better!

choices.text: Blame someone else for the blocks falling
choices.explanation: Sometimes things just happen! It's better to focus on how we can handle our feelings and try again!

endingMessage: You handled those big feelings so well! Feeling angry is normal, and you found healthy ways to calm down. That's a superpower! üí™

title: Too Loud!
story: Mouse was at a birthday party with lots of kids running around, music playing, and everyone talking loudly. Mouse felt overwhelmed by all the noise and wanted to hide. What should Mouse do?
imagePrompt: A small mouse looking overwhelmed at a noisy birthday party

choices.text: Find a quiet corner to take a break, ask a grown-up for help, or step outside for fresh air
choices.explanation: Perfect! It's okay to need quiet time. Finding a calm space or asking for help shows you know how to take care of yourself!

choices.text: Start crying and run away
choices.explanation: Running away might make you feel more scared. It's better to find a quiet spot or ask a grown-up for help!

choices.text: Try to ignore it and stay in the loud room
choices.explanation: It's okay to try, but if the noise feels too much, it's perfectly fine to take a break! Taking care of ourselves is important!

choices.text: Yell at everyone to be quiet
choices.explanation: Yelling might make things louder! It's better to find a quiet space or ask a grown-up for help!

endingMessage: You listened to your body! When things feel too loud or overwhelming, taking a break is a smart choice. You're learning to take care of yourself! üéà

title: Not Winning
story: Frog was playing a game with friends and kept losing. Every time they didn't win, Frog felt upset and wanted to quit playing. What should Frog do?
imagePrompt: A frog looking upset after losing a game, with friends nearby

choices.text: Remember that games are for fun, congratulate the winner, and keep playing
choices.explanation: Wonderful attitude! Games are about having fun together, not just winning. Being a good sport makes everyone happy!

choices.text: Quit the game and go home
choices.explanation: Quitting might make you miss out on fun! Remember, games are about playing together, not just winning!

choices.text: Keep playing but feel grumpy
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel a little upset, but trying to have fun even when we don't win helps us enjoy the game more!

choices.text: Change the rules so they can win
choices.explanation: Changing rules isn't fair to others. It's better to remember that playing together is what makes games fun!

endingMessage: You're learning to be a great sport! Winning is fun, but playing together and having fun is even more important. You're a wonderful friend! üéÆ

title: Group Work Worries
story: Deer was put in a group for a school project, but the other group members weren't doing their part. Deer felt stressed because they were doing all the work and worried about getting a bad grade. What should Deer do?
imagePrompt: A deer looking stressed, surrounded by group project materials while other animals aren't helping

choices.text: Talk to the teacher about the situation, try to divide tasks clearly with group members, and ask for help if needed
choices.explanation: Excellent problem-solving! Talking to the teacher and trying to work together fairly is the right approach. You don't have to handle it alone!

choices.text: Do all the work alone without saying anything
choices.explanation: Doing everything alone isn't fair to you and doesn't help your group learn to work together. It's okay to ask for help!

choices.text: Get angry and refuse to work with the group
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel frustrated, but getting angry usually makes things harder. Talking about the problem usually works better!

choices.text: Blame the group members to the teacher
choices.explanation: It's better to focus on solving the problem together rather than blaming. Talking to the teacher about finding solutions helps everyone!

endingMessage: You handled that challenge well! Group work can be tricky, but learning to communicate and ask for help is an important skill. You're growing! üìã

title: Words That Hurt
story: Hedgehog's classmates were making fun of their new haircut. They kept laughing and saying mean things. Hedgehog felt hurt and embarrassed. What should Hedgehog do?
imagePrompt: A hedgehog looking sad while other animals laugh nearby

choices.text: Tell a teacher or trusted adult, remember that mean words say more about the speaker than you, and spend time with kind friends
choices.explanation: Perfect response! Telling an adult and remembering that you're wonderful just as you are is the right way to handle this. Mean words don't define you!

choices.text: Say mean things back
choices.explanation: Saying mean things back usually makes things worse. It's better to tell an adult and remember that you're awesome just as you are!

choices.text: Pretend it doesn't bother them
choices.explanation: It's okay to try to ignore it, but if mean words hurt, it's important to tell someone. You don't have to handle it alone!

choices.text: Change their appearance to fit in
choices.explanation: You shouldn't have to change who you are! Being yourself is what makes you special. It's better to tell an adult about the teasing!

endingMessage: You're strong and wonderful just as you are! Mean words say more about the people saying them than about you. Remember, you're amazing! üí™

title: Busy as a Bee
story: Bee was signed up for soccer, piano lessons, art class, and swimming - all in one week! Bee felt exhausted and didn't have time to just play or relax. What should Bee do?
imagePrompt: A tired bee surrounded by sports equipment, musical instruments, and art supplies

choices.text: Talk to parents about feeling overwhelmed, choose favorite activities, and make sure there's time for rest and play
choices.explanation: Great self-awareness! It's important to have balance. Talking about how you feel and choosing what you love most helps you enjoy activities more!

choices.text: Keep doing everything even though they're exhausted
choices.explanation: Being exhausted all the time isn't healthy! It's okay to slow down and choose what you really love. Rest is important too!

choices.text: Feel guilty about wanting to quit something
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel a little guilty, but it's okay to choose what you love! Having time to rest and play is important for growing kids!

choices.text: Quit everything without talking to anyone
choices.explanation: Talking about your feelings first is better than quitting everything! You might find a balance that works for everyone!

endingMessage: You're learning about balance! Having fun activities is great, but rest and free play time are important too. You're doing great! ‚öñÔ∏è

title: Oops, I Made a Mistake
story: Monkey accidentally broke a friend's favorite pencil during art class. The friend looked upset, and Monkey felt embarrassed and didn't know what to say. What should Monkey do?
imagePrompt: A monkey looking embarrassed, holding a broken pencil while a friend looks sad

choices.text: Apologize sincerely, offer to replace it or help fix it, and learn to be more careful
choices.explanation: Perfect! Saying sorry and trying to make it right shows you care. Everyone makes mistakes - what matters is how we handle them!

choices.text: Pretend it wasn't them
choices.explanation: Pretending won't make things better and might hurt the friendship. It's better to be honest and apologize!

choices.text: Feel too embarrassed to say anything
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel embarrassed, but saying sorry helps fix things. Your friend will probably understand - accidents happen!

choices.text: Blame someone else
choices.explanation: Blaming others isn't fair and won't help. Taking responsibility and apologizing is the right thing to do!

endingMessage: You showed great character! Making mistakes is part of learning, and you handled it the right way. That's what good friends do! ‚úèÔ∏è

title: Online World
story: Flamingo's friends were all on a social media app, but Flamingo's parents said they weren't old enough yet. Flamingo felt left out and pressured to join secretly. What should Flamingo do?
imagePrompt: A flamingo looking at a phone while friends are using social media, feeling left out

choices.text: Talk to parents about feelings, find other ways to connect with friends, and respect the family rules
choices.explanation: Excellent decision! Talking about your feelings and finding other ways to connect shows maturity. Family rules are there to keep you safe!

choices.text: Join secretly without telling parents
choices.explanation: Going behind parents' backs breaks trust and can be unsafe. It's better to talk about your feelings and find solutions together!

choices.text: Feel angry and resentful toward parents
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel frustrated, but talking about it helps. Your parents want to keep you safe - maybe you can find a compromise!

choices.text: Stop being friends with people who use the app
choices.explanation: You don't have to stop being friends! There are lots of ways to connect with friends that don't involve social media!

endingMessage: You showed great maturity! Respecting family rules while finding ways to connect with friends shows you're growing up responsibly. You're doing great! üì±

title: Changing Body
story: Caterpillar noticed their body was changing - growing taller, voice changing, and feeling different. They felt self-conscious and worried about what others thought. What should Caterpillar do?
imagePrompt: A caterpillar looking at their reflection, feeling self-conscious about changes

choices.text: Remember that body changes are normal, talk to trusted adults about questions, and focus on being healthy and happy
choices.explanation: Perfect! Body changes are a normal part of growing up. Everyone goes through it, and talking to trusted adults helps us understand what's happening!

choices.text: Try to hide or change their body
choices.explanation: Our bodies are changing naturally, and that's okay! Trying to change or hide our bodies isn't healthy. Everyone goes through this!

choices.text: Worry constantly about what others think
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel self-conscious, but remember - everyone your age is going through changes too! You're not alone!

choices.text: Avoid looking in mirrors completely
choices.explanation: Avoiding our reflection won't make the changes go away. It's better to learn that these changes are normal and part of growing up!

endingMessage: You're growing up beautifully! Body changes are a normal part of becoming a teenager. Everyone goes through this - you're not alone! Remember, you're amazing just as you are! üå±

title: High Expectations
story: Hawk's parents and teachers kept talking about getting good grades for middle school and high school. Hawk felt pressured to be perfect and worried about disappointing everyone. What should Hawk do?
imagePrompt: A hawk surrounded by books and report cards, looking stressed about expectations

choices.text: Talk to parents and teachers about feeling pressured, focus on doing their best rather than being perfect, and remember that mistakes help us learn
choices.explanation: Excellent! Talking about pressure and focusing on doing your best (not being perfect) is healthy. Learning from mistakes is part of growing!

choices.text: Try to be perfect at everything
choices.explanation: Trying to be perfect usually leads to stress and burnout. It's better to do your best and learn from mistakes - that's how we grow!

choices.text: Feel stressed but not say anything
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel stressed, but talking about it helps! Adults want to support you, not pressure you. Let them know how you feel!

choices.text: Give up on schoolwork completely
choices.explanation: Giving up won't help! It's better to talk about the pressure and find a balance between doing well and taking care of yourself!

endingMessage: You're learning important life skills! Doing your best is what matters, not being perfect. Talking about pressure helps adults support you better. You've got this! üìö

title: Disagreement with Friend
story: Raccoon and their best friend had a big disagreement about something important. Both felt strongly about their side, and neither wanted to back down. Raccoon felt conflicted - they didn't want to lose the friendship. What should Raccoon do?
imagePrompt: Two raccoons having a disagreement, both looking upset

choices.text: Take a break to cool down, listen to the friend's perspective, share their own feelings calmly, and try to find a solution together
choices.explanation: Perfect approach! Taking time to cool down and then listening to each other helps resolve conflicts. Good friendships can handle disagreements!

choices.text: Refuse to talk to the friend ever again
choices.explanation: Ending a friendship over one disagreement usually makes us feel worse. It's better to try to work through conflicts together!

choices.text: Give in completely just to keep the friendship
choices.explanation: It's okay to compromise, but giving in completely isn't healthy. Good friendships allow both people to share their feelings!

choices.text: Get other friends to take their side
choices.explanation: Getting others involved usually makes conflicts bigger. It's better to work things out directly with your friend!

endingMessage: You showed great maturity! Disagreements happen in even the best friendships. Learning to communicate and work through conflicts is an important skill. You're growing! üí¨

title: Hard Goodbyes
story: Koala's best friend was moving far away. They wouldn't be able to play together every day anymore. Koala felt very sad about saying goodbye. What should Koala do?
imagePrompt: A koala looking sad while hugging a friend who is about to move away

choices.text: Give a special goodbye hug, make a drawing to remember them, and know they can still be friends even far apart
choices.explanation: Wonderful! Saying goodbye in a special way and making memories helps us feel better. Friends can stay friends even when they're far away!

choices.text: Hide so they don't have to say goodbye
choices.explanation: Hiding might make you both feel worse. Saying goodbye properly helps us feel better and lets our friend know we care!

choices.text: Cry and feel sad all day
choices.explanation: It's okay to cry and feel sad - that's normal when someone we love is leaving. But doing something special together can help too!

choices.text: Pretend they don't care
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel sad! Pretending we don't care won't make the sad feelings go away. It's better to share our feelings!

endingMessage: You showed so much love! Saying goodbye is hard, but making special memories helps us remember our friends. Distance can't break true friendship! üíô

title: Missing Mommy
story: Lamb's parent had to go away for work for a few days. Lamb felt sad and missed them a lot. They didn't want to play or eat without their parent. What should Lamb do?
imagePrompt: A lamb looking sad, holding a photo of their parent who is away

choices.text: Talk about missing them with the other grown-up, look at photos together, and draw a picture to share when they return
choices.explanation: Perfect! Talking about our feelings and doing special activities helps us feel connected even when someone we love is away!

choices.text: Refuse to eat or play until they come back
choices.explanation: Not eating or playing won't make them come back faster, and it might make you feel worse. It's okay to have fun while you wait!

choices.text: Cry all day and night
choices.explanation: It's okay to cry when we miss someone! But doing other things can help too - we can miss someone and still have fun!

choices.text: Pretend they don't miss them
choices.explanation: Missing someone we love is normal! It's okay to feel sad. Talking about it helps us feel better!

endingMessage: You're so loving! Missing someone we love shows how much we care. Remember, they'll be back soon, and doing fun things helps the time pass! üíï

title: Try Something New
story: Porcupine's grown-up made a new food for dinner that looked strange and different. Porcupine felt scared to try it because they didn't know what it would taste like. What should Porcupine do?
imagePrompt: A porcupine looking uncertainly at a plate of new food they've never tried before

choices.text: Take one tiny bite to try it, knowing they can say if they don't like it
choices.explanation: Great courage! Trying new things helps us discover what we like. One small bite is all it takes to try something new!

choices.text: Refuse to try it and refuse to eat dinner
choices.explanation: Not eating dinner might make you hungry! Trying just one tiny bite is a brave way to see if you like something new!

choices.text: Push the plate away and ask for something else
choices.explanation: It's okay to be scared of new foods, but trying one small bite first is a great way to be brave! You might discover something yummy!

choices.text: Say they're not hungry even though they are
choices.explanation: It's okay to tell grown-ups we're scared! They can help us try new things. One small bite won't hurt - you might like it!

endingMessage: You're so brave! Trying new foods can be scary, but being willing to try just one bite shows courage. You might discover something delicious! üçΩÔ∏è

title: Check-Up Time
story: Giraffe had to go to the doctor for a check-up. They remembered getting a shot last time and felt nervous about going back. Giraffe didn't want to go. What should Giraffe do?
imagePrompt: A giraffe looking nervous at a doctor's office, with a friendly doctor nearby

choices.text: Tell a grown-up about being nervous, bring a favorite toy, and remember that doctors help keep us healthy
choices.explanation: Perfect! Talking about our feelings helps. Doctors are helpers who want to keep us healthy and strong - even if some parts aren't fun!

choices.text: Hide so they don't have to go
choices.explanation: Hiding won't help - doctors help keep us healthy! It's better to talk about our fears and bring something comforting!

choices.text: Cry and refuse to go
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel scared, but going to the doctor is important for staying healthy. Bringing a toy or talking about it can help!

choices.text: Pretend to be sick so they can't go
choices.explanation: Doctors help us stay healthy! It's better to talk about being nervous and bring something that makes us feel brave!

endingMessage: You're so brave! Going to the doctor can feel scary, but you handled it well. Doctors help us grow strong and healthy - that's important! üè•

title: Promise Not Kept
story: Panda's grown-up promised they would go to the park today, but it started raining and they couldn't go. Panda felt disappointed and sad. What should Panda do?
imagePrompt: A panda looking out the window at rain, feeling disappointed about a cancelled park visit

choices.text: Feel disappointed but understand, and ask to do something fun inside instead
choices.explanation: Great flexibility! Sometimes things don't work out the way we planned. Finding a fun alternative shows we can adapt!

choices.text: Get angry and have a tantrum
choices.explanation: Getting angry won't make it stop raining! It's better to talk about our feelings and find something fun to do inside instead!

choices.text: Feel sad and refuse to do anything else
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel disappointed! But maybe doing something fun inside could help us feel better while we wait for the sun!

choices.text: Go to the park anyway in the rain
choices.explanation: Going in the rain might not be safe or fun. It's better to find something fun to do inside and go to the park another day!

endingMessage: You showed great understanding! Sometimes things don't work out the way we plan, but finding fun alternatives helps us enjoy the day anyway! ‚òî

title: Wanting to Be in Charge
story: Peacock wanted to choose the game and tell everyone what to do during playtime. When friends wanted to play something else, Peacock felt frustrated and upset. What should Peacock do?
imagePrompt: A peacock looking frustrated while friends want to play a different game

choices.text: Take turns choosing games, listen to friends' ideas, and remember that playing together means everyone gets a say
choices.explanation: Perfect! Taking turns and listening to others helps everyone have fun. When we share decisions, playtime is more fun for everyone!

choices.text: Refuse to play unless it's their way
choices.explanation: That might make friends not want to play with us. Taking turns choosing games helps everyone feel included and happy!

choices.text: Get upset but still play what friends want
choices.explanation: It's okay to want to choose, but taking turns means everyone gets to pick sometimes. That's fair and fun!

choices.text: Go play alone instead
choices.explanation: Playing alone is okay sometimes, but playing together and taking turns can be more fun! Everyone gets to choose sometimes!

endingMessage: You're learning to be a great friend! Taking turns and listening to others makes playtime fun for everyone. You're becoming a wonderful playmate! üéÆ

title: Cleaning Up
story: Hedgehog's room was very messy with toys everywhere. A grown-up asked them to clean up, but Hedgehog felt tired and didn't want to. It seemed like too much work. What should Hedgehog do?
imagePrompt: A hedgehog looking at a very messy room full of toys, feeling overwhelmed

choices.text: Put away toys one at a time, maybe sing a clean-up song, and ask for help if it's too much
choices.explanation: Wonderful! Breaking big jobs into small steps makes them easier. One toy at a time, and soon the room will be clean!

choices.text: Refuse to clean and hide under the bed
choices.explanation: Hiding won't make the mess go away! Starting with just one toy helps us get started, and it gets easier!

choices.text: Feel too tired and leave it all messy
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel tired, but cleaning even just a few toys helps! Starting small makes the whole job feel easier!

choices.text: Push all toys under the bed
choices.explanation: That's not really cleaning - it's hiding! Putting toys in their proper places makes the room nice and helps us find things later!

endingMessage: You did great! Cleaning can feel like a big job, but doing it little by little makes it easier. A clean room feels nice! üßπ

title: New Family Member
story: Owl's family had a new baby, and grown-ups were spending lots of time with the baby. Owl felt jealous and missed getting all the attention. What should Owl do?
imagePrompt: An owl looking at a new baby sibling while grown-ups give the baby attention

choices.text: Talk about feelings with a grown-up, ask for special time together, and remember they're still loved just as much
choices.explanation: Perfect! Talking about our feelings helps grown-ups understand. They love you just as much - babies just need extra help sometimes!

choices.text: Act out to get attention
choices.explanation: Acting out might make things harder. It's better to talk about our feelings and ask for special time together!

choices.text: Ignore the baby completely
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel jealous, but the baby is part of your family now. Talking about your feelings can help everyone!

choices.text: Try to be a baby too
choices.explanation: You're special just as you are! Talking about feeling left out helps grown-ups make sure you get special time too!

endingMessage: You're so important! A new baby doesn't mean you're loved any less. You're still special, and talking about your feelings helps grown-ups understand! üë∂

title: Scary Dream
story: Bunny woke up from a bad dream and felt scared. They thought the scary things from the dream might be real. Bunny's heart was beating fast and they didn't want to go back to sleep. What should Bunny do?
imagePrompt: A bunny in bed looking scared after waking from a bad dream

choices.text: Tell a grown-up about the dream, get a hug, and remember that dreams aren't real - they're just thoughts while we sleep
choices.explanation: Excellent! Telling someone about scary dreams helps us feel better. Dreams are just stories our minds make up while we sleep - they can't hurt us!

choices.text: Stay awake all night because they're too scared
choices.explanation: Staying awake all night will make you very tired! Talking about the dream helps us feel better and reminds us that dreams aren't real!

choices.text: Hide under the covers and try to forget
choices.explanation: Hiding can feel safe for a moment, but talking about scary dreams with a grown-up helps us feel much better!

choices.text: Think about the scary dream over and over
choices.explanation: Thinking about scary things makes them feel bigger! It's better to tell someone and think about happy things instead!

endingMessage: You're so brave! Bad dreams can feel very scary, but telling someone helps. Remember, dreams are just stories - they can't hurt you! Sweet dreams! üåô

title: Not Following Rules
story: Fox wanted to keep playing, but a grown-up said it was time to stop. Fox felt frustrated and talked back, saying 'No!' even though they knew they should listen. What should Fox do?
imagePrompt: A fox looking frustrated while a grown-up asks them to stop playing

choices.text: Take a deep breath, stop playing, and ask nicely if they can play more later
choices.explanation: Perfect! Sometimes we need to stop things we enjoy, and that's hard! But listening and asking nicely shows we're growing up!

choices.text: Keep playing and ignore the grown-up
choices.explanation: Ignoring grown-ups usually makes things harder. It's better to listen, even when we don't want to - grown-ups keep us safe and healthy!

choices.text: Get upset but eventually stop
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel frustrated, but listening the first time makes things easier for everyone. You can ask about playing more later!

choices.text: Yell and have a tantrum
choices.explanation: Yelling usually makes things harder. Taking a breath and listening shows we're learning to handle our feelings!

endingMessage: You're learning self-control! It's hard to stop doing something fun, but listening and asking nicely shows you're growing up. Great job! üëè

title: Family Pet
story: Dog's family was getting a pet hamster! Dog felt very excited and wanted to play with it all the time. They kept asking to hold it and play, even when the hamster was sleeping. What should Dog do?
imagePrompt: An excited dog looking at a hamster in a cage, wanting to play with it

choices.text: Ask a grown-up when it's okay to play, be gentle when handling it, and remember pets need rest too
choices.explanation: Wonderful! Being gentle and patient with pets shows we care about them. Pets need rest just like we do, so waiting for the right time is kind!

choices.text: Play with it whenever they want, even if it's sleeping
choices.explanation: Pets need rest just like we do! Waking them up isn't kind. It's better to wait for the right time and be gentle!

choices.text: Feel too excited to wait
choices.explanation: Being excited is great! But pets need gentle care and rest. Asking grown-ups when it's okay to play is the best way to care for pets!

choices.text: Try to take it out of the cage without asking
choices.explanation: That could be unsafe! Always ask a grown-up before handling pets. They'll show you the safe and gentle way!

endingMessage: You're learning to be a great pet owner! Being gentle and patient with pets shows you care. Taking care of pets is a big responsibility! üêπ

title: Stage Fright
story: Canary had to sing a solo in the school concert. They practiced a lot but felt very nervous about singing in front of everyone. Canary worried about making mistakes. What should Canary do?
imagePrompt: A canary on a stage looking nervous, with an audience in front of them

choices.text: Take deep breaths, remember they practiced well, focus on having fun, and know that everyone supports them
choices.explanation: Excellent! Nervous feelings are normal, but you prepared well! Remember, everyone in the audience wants you to succeed and is cheering for you!

choices.text: Panic and refuse to go on stage
choices.explanation: Refusing to perform might make you feel worse later. You practiced - you can do this! Taking deep breaths helps calm those nervous feelings!

choices.text: Feel so nervous they can't think straight
choices.explanation: Feeling nervous is normal! Deep breathing helps. Remember, you practiced well and everyone is on your side!

choices.text: Try to skip the concert entirely
choices.explanation: Skipping would miss all your hard work! It's okay to be nervous, but you prepared for this. You've got this!

endingMessage: You were so brave! Feeling nervous before performing is completely normal. You practiced hard, and that's what matters most. Well done! üé§

title: Friend Groups
story: Meerkat noticed that some friends were only playing with certain kids and not including others. Meerkat wanted to be friends with everyone but felt confused about which group to join. What should Meerkat do?
imagePrompt: A meerkat looking confused, watching different friend groups at recess

choices.text: Be friendly to everyone, play with different groups on different days, and invite others to join games
choices.explanation: Perfect approach! You don't have to choose just one group - being friendly to everyone and including others makes you a great friend!

choices.text: Pick one group and ignore everyone else
choices.explanation: You don't have to limit yourself to one group! Being friendly to everyone and playing with different kids makes school more fun!

choices.text: Feel confused and not play with anyone
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel confused, but you don't have to choose just one group! Being friendly to everyone is the best way to be!

choices.text: Try to make everyone join one big group
choices.explanation: That's a nice idea, but people like different things. It's okay to have different friend groups - you can be friends with everyone!

endingMessage: You're becoming a wonderful friend! Being kind to everyone and not limiting yourself to one group shows maturity. You're inclusive and caring! üë•

title: Lost Treasure
story: Badger lost a special necklace their grandparent gave them. They looked everywhere but couldn't find it. Badger felt worried they would never see it again and sad about losing something important. What should Badger do?
imagePrompt: A badger looking worried, searching for a lost special necklace

choices.text: Ask grown-ups for help searching, check lost and found at school, retrace steps from the last time they remember having it
choices.explanation: Great problem-solving! Asking for help and thinking carefully about where you last had it gives the best chance of finding it!

choices.text: Give up searching and feel terrible forever
choices.explanation: Don't give up! Asking for help and thinking about where you last saw it can help you find it. It might turn up in an unexpected place!

choices.text: Keep looking in the same places over and over
choices.explanation: It's good to keep trying, but asking for help and thinking about new places to look can help! Sometimes things turn up in surprising places!

choices.text: Blame someone else for taking it
choices.explanation: Blaming others won't help find it. It's better to focus on searching and asking for help. Most things we lose are just misplaced!

endingMessage: You showed persistence! Losing something important is scary, but not giving up and asking for help gives us the best chance of finding it. Don't lose hope! üîç

title: Mean Words
story: Wolverine's classmate said something mean about their artwork. Wolverine felt angry and wanted to say something mean back. They felt like fighting back would make them feel better. What should Wolverine do?
imagePrompt: A wolverine looking angry, with torn artwork nearby and a classmate in the background

choices.text: Walk away, take deep breaths, tell a teacher, and remember that mean words don't change how great their art is
choices.explanation: Excellent self-control! Walking away and not saying mean things back shows maturity. Mean words say more about the person saying them than about you!

choices.text: Say mean things back right away
choices.explanation: Saying mean things back usually makes conflicts worse. It's better to walk away, calm down, and tell a teacher if someone is being mean!

choices.text: Feel angry but not do anything
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel angry, but telling a teacher helps. They can help stop the mean behavior and make things better!

choices.text: Try to get other friends to be mean back too
choices.explanation: Getting others involved usually makes things worse. It's better to handle it calmly by walking away and telling a teacher!

endingMessage: You showed great maturity! Not saying mean things back takes strength. Your artwork is wonderful, and mean words can't change that! üé®

title: New School, New Friends
story: Parrot was switching to a new school in the middle of the year. They worried about leaving old friends behind and not fitting in at the new school. Parrot felt anxious about starting over. What should Parrot do?
imagePrompt: A parrot looking at a new school building, feeling anxious about starting there

choices.text: Keep in touch with old friends, be open to making new friends, join activities, and remember that many kids feel nervous starting a new school
choices.explanation: Perfect approach! You can keep old friends AND make new ones! Being friendly and joining activities helps you fit in. Everyone feels nervous starting somewhere new!

choices.text: Refuse to talk to anyone at the new school
choices.explanation: That would make it harder to make friends! Being friendly and open helps you fit in. You can make new friends while keeping old ones!

choices.text: Only think about missing old friends
choices.explanation: It's okay to miss old friends, but you can keep them AND make new ones! Being open to new friendships helps you feel happy in both places!

choices.text: Try to act exactly like kids at the new school to fit in
choices.explanation: You don't have to change who you are! Being yourself is what makes you special. True friends will like you for who you are!

endingMessage: You're so brave! Starting a new school is challenging, but you can keep old friends and make new ones. Being yourself and being friendly helps you fit in! üéí

title: I Don't Get It
story: Otter was trying to do math homework but couldn't understand how to solve the problems. They read the instructions over and over but still felt confused. Otter felt frustrated and wanted to give up. What should Otter do?
imagePrompt: An otter looking frustrated at a math worksheet with difficult problems

choices.text: Ask a parent or teacher for help, try breaking the problem into smaller steps, and remember that asking for help is smart
choices.explanation: Excellent! Asking for help is a sign of intelligence, not weakness. Everyone needs help sometimes, and that's how we learn!

choices.text: Give up and not do the homework
choices.explanation: Giving up won't help you learn! Asking for help shows you're trying. Everyone needs help with hard things sometimes!

choices.text: Keep trying the same way over and over
choices.explanation: It's good to keep trying, but if something isn't working, asking for help is the smart thing to do. That's how we learn!

choices.text: Copy answers from a friend
choices.explanation: Copying won't help you learn! Asking for help so you understand is much better. Understanding is more important than just getting answers!

endingMessage: You showed wisdom! Asking for help when something is hard is smart. Everyone needs help learning new things - that's how we grow! üìö

title: Last to Be Chosen
story: Turtle was always one of the last kids picked for teams in gym class. They weren't very fast or strong, and it made them feel left out and sad. What should Turtle do?
imagePrompt: A turtle waiting to be picked for a team, looking left out while other animals are chosen first

choices.text: Remember they have other strengths, keep trying their best, and focus on having fun rather than being the best
choices.explanation: Perfect mindset! Everyone has different strengths - being fast isn't everything! Having fun and trying your best is what matters most!

choices.text: Refuse to play and sit out
choices.explanation: Sitting out might make you feel more left out. Playing and having fun, even if you're not the fastest, is better than not playing at all!

choices.text: Feel bad about themselves and think they're not good at anything
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel sad, but remember - everyone is good at different things! You have many strengths, even if they're not in sports!

choices.text: Try to force themselves to be faster
choices.explanation: You don't have to change who you are! Being good at sports isn't everything. Focus on having fun and doing your best - that's what matters!

endingMessage: You're wonderful just as you are! Everyone has different strengths, and being fast isn't everything. Having fun and trying your best is what matters! üèÉ

title: Everyone's Moving Faster
story: Sloth noticed that other kids were learning to read faster or solving math problems quicker. Sloth felt frustrated and worried they weren't as smart as everyone else. What should Sloth do?
imagePrompt: A sloth looking frustrated, watching other animals work faster on school tasks

choices.text: Remember that everyone learns at their own pace, focus on their own progress, and celebrate their achievements
choices.explanation: Perfect! Everyone learns differently and at different speeds. What matters is your own progress, not how fast others are going!

choices.text: Give up because they think they can't keep up
choices.explanation: Don't give up! Everyone learns at their own pace. What matters is that you're learning and growing, not how fast you do it!

choices.text: Compare themselves to others constantly
choices.explanation: Comparing usually makes us feel worse! Focus on your own progress and celebrate how much you've learned. Everyone is on their own journey!

choices.text: Try to rush and work faster even if they make mistakes
choices.explanation: Rushing usually leads to mistakes! It's better to work at your own pace and do your best work. Speed isn't everything!

endingMessage: You're learning beautifully! Everyone learns at their own pace, and that's perfect. What matters is that you're growing and trying your best! üå±

title: Endless Homework
story: Ant had homework every single day and on weekends too. They felt like there was never time to just play or relax. Ant felt overwhelmed and exhausted. What should Ant do?
imagePrompt: An ant surrounded by piles of homework, looking overwhelmed and tired

choices.text: Talk to parents and teachers about the workload, ask for help prioritizing, and make sure there's time for breaks and play
choices.explanation: Excellent! Everyone needs time to rest and play. Talking about feeling overwhelmed helps adults understand and find a healthy balance!

choices.text: Keep working until they're too exhausted to do anything
choices.explanation: Working until exhaustion isn't healthy! Kids need time to play and rest. Talking about the workload helps find a better balance!

choices.text: Feel stressed but not say anything
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel overwhelmed, but talking about it helps! Adults want to help you find a healthy balance between work and play!

choices.text: Just stop doing homework completely
choices.explanation: Stopping completely might cause problems. It's better to talk about feeling overwhelmed and work together to find a healthy balance!

endingMessage: You're learning balance! Everyone needs time for work AND play. Talking about feeling overwhelmed helps adults support you better. You're doing great! ‚öñÔ∏è

title: Wanting to Give Up
story: Pig started learning piano but found it harder than expected. They kept making mistakes and felt like they'd never get better. Pig wanted to quit and felt discouraged. What should Pig do?
imagePrompt: A pig looking discouraged at a piano, with sheet music scattered around

choices.text: Remember that learning takes time, practice a little each day, celebrate small improvements, and talk to the teacher about struggles
choices.explanation: Perfect attitude! Learning new things is hard at first, but everyone starts as a beginner. Small improvements add up over time!

choices.text: Quit immediately because it's too hard
choices.explanation: Giving up when things get hard means missing out on getting better! Everyone struggles when learning something new - that's normal!

choices.text: Feel discouraged and avoid practicing
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel discouraged, but avoiding practice won't help. Even a little practice each day helps you improve gradually!

choices.text: Compare themselves to kids who've played for years
choices.explanation: Comparing to experts isn't fair to yourself! Everyone starts as a beginner. Focus on your own progress and celebrate small wins!

endingMessage: You're showing persistence! Learning new things is always hard at first. Every expert was once a beginner. Keep practicing - you'll get better! üéπ

title: Secret Keeper
story: Whale's best friend told them a secret that worried them. The friend said not to tell anyone, but Whale thought an adult should know because the friend might be in trouble. Whale felt torn about what to do. What should Whale do?
imagePrompt: A whale looking conflicted, with a friend in the background who shared a concerning secret

choices.text: Talk to the friend about their concern, explain why telling an adult might be necessary for safety, and tell a trusted adult if it's serious
choices.explanation: Excellent judgment! Sometimes keeping secrets isn't safe. If someone might be hurt or in danger, telling a trusted adult is the right thing to do, even if it's hard!

choices.text: Keep the secret no matter what, even if it's dangerous
choices.explanation: Some secrets shouldn't be kept - especially if someone might get hurt. It's okay to break a promise if it's to keep someone safe!

choices.text: Feel torn but do nothing
choices.explanation: It's hard when you're torn, but if someone might be in danger, it's important to tell a trusted adult. Safety comes first!

choices.text: Tell all their friends instead of an adult
choices.explanation: If something serious is happening, telling other kids won't help. A trusted adult is the right person to tell for serious concerns!

endingMessage: You showed great wisdom! Sometimes being a good friend means telling an adult when someone might be unsafe. That takes courage and shows you care! üõ°Ô∏è

title: Not in the Popular Crowd
story: Peacock noticed there was a 'popular' group at school that everyone wanted to be part of. Peacock wasn't included and felt left out and like something was wrong with them. What should Peacock do?
imagePrompt: A peacock watching a popular group from a distance, feeling left out

choices.text: Focus on being a good friend to the friends they have, remember that popularity doesn't equal happiness, and be themselves
choices.explanation: Perfect mindset! True friendships are more valuable than popularity. Being yourself and being a good friend is what really matters!

choices.text: Change everything about themselves to try to fit in
choices.explanation: Changing who you are to fit in usually doesn't work and won't make you happy. True friends like you for who you really are!

choices.text: Feel bad about themselves and think they're not good enough
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel left out, but remember - you're wonderful just as you are! Popularity doesn't determine your worth!

choices.text: Try to force their way into the popular group
choices.explanation: Forcing yourself into groups usually doesn't work well. Focus on being a great friend to the people who appreciate you for who you are!

endingMessage: You're amazing just as you are! Popularity isn't everything - real friendships and being yourself are what bring true happiness. You're wonderful! üåü

title: Screen Time Limits
story: Robot loved playing video games and being online, but their parents set strict time limits. All their friends seemed to have more screen time, and Robot felt frustrated about the rules. What should Robot do?
imagePrompt: A robot looking frustrated while a parent sets screen time limits, with a gaming console in the background

choices.text: Talk to parents about feelings, ask about the reasoning behind rules, suggest a compromise, and find fun offline activities too
choices.explanation: Excellent approach! Talking about your feelings and understanding the reasons for rules helps. Finding balance between online and offline fun is healthy!

choices.text: Sneak screen time when parents aren't watching
choices.explanation: Breaking rules breaks trust and usually leads to bigger problems. It's better to talk about your feelings and work together on solutions!

choices.text: Feel angry and resentful about the rules
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel frustrated, but talking about it helps! Parents set rules to help you, and discussing them can lead to understanding or compromise!

choices.text: Compare their screen time to friends constantly
choices.explanation: Comparing to friends won't help! Every family has different rules. Focus on talking to your parents about your feelings and finding solutions together!

endingMessage: You showed maturity! Talking about feelings and working with parents on rules is grown-up behavior. Balance is important for staying healthy and happy! üíª

title: Parents Arguing
story: Elephant's parents were arguing more than usual lately. They seemed stressed and upset with each other. Elephant felt worried that something was wrong with the family. What should Elephant do?
imagePrompt: An elephant looking worried, with parents arguing in the background

choices.text: Talk to a trusted adult about worries, remember it's not their fault, know that adults sometimes disagree, and take care of themselves
choices.explanation: Perfect understanding! Parents' arguments aren't your fault. Talking to a trusted adult helps, and remember that adults sometimes disagree - that's normal!

choices.text: Blame themselves for the arguments
choices.explanation: Parents' arguments are never your fault! Adults have their own issues. It's important to know you didn't cause it and you can't fix it!

choices.text: Feel worried but not talk to anyone
choices.explanation: It's normal to worry, but talking to a trusted adult helps. Remember, adults sometimes disagree - that's normal and it's not your fault!

choices.text: Try to fix their parents' problems
choices.explanation: Adult problems are for adults to solve, not kids. It's not your job to fix it. Focus on taking care of yourself and talking to trusted adults!

endingMessage: You're strong and wise! Remember, parents' problems are never your fault. Talking to trusted adults helps, and focusing on yourself is important. You're doing great! üíô

title: Nobody Gets Me
story: Chameleon felt like their interests and thoughts were very different from other kids at school. They had trouble finding friends who understood them. Chameleon felt isolated and alone. What should Chameleon do?
imagePrompt: A chameleon looking isolated, surrounded by other animals who seem different

choices.text: Join clubs or activities related to their interests, be open to connecting over similarities, and remember that being different is special
choices.explanation: Excellent! Finding people with similar interests helps. Being different makes you special, and you can connect with others over what you have in common!

choices.text: Change everything about themselves to fit in
choices.explanation: Changing who you are won't make you happy. Being yourself helps you find people who appreciate the real you - and they're out there!

choices.text: Give up on making friends completely
choices.explanation: Don't give up! There are people out there who will appreciate you. Joining activities related to your interests is a great way to meet like-minded friends!

choices.text: Pretend to like things they don't just to fit in
choices.explanation: Pretending won't help you find real friends. Being genuine helps you connect with people who truly appreciate you for who you are!

endingMessage: You're unique and special! Being different is a strength. Finding activities and clubs related to your interests is a great way to meet friends who get you! üåà

title: Worrying About Tomorrow
story: Owl worried constantly about the future - middle school, high school, college, getting a job. They felt anxious thinking about all the big decisions ahead and whether they'd make the right choices. What should Owl do?
imagePrompt: An owl looking anxious, surrounded by images representing future worries about school and career

choices.text: Focus on the present, take things one step at a time, talk to trusted adults about worries, and remember that everyone figures things out gradually
choices.explanation: Perfect! Worrying about the future doesn't help. Focus on today, take things step by step, and remember - everyone figures out their path gradually. You don't have to have all the answers now!

choices.text: Worry constantly about every future decision
choices.explanation: Worrying won't help you prepare! Focus on doing your best today. You'll figure things out as you go - that's how everyone does it!

choices.text: Feel anxious but try to ignore it
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel anxious, but talking about it helps! Remember, you don't need to figure everything out right now. Take things one step at a time!

choices.text: Try to plan out their entire life right now
choices.explanation: You can't plan everything right now - and that's okay! Life changes, and people figure things out as they go. Focus on today!

endingMessage: You're thoughtful about your future! But remember - you don't have to figure everything out right now. Focus on today, do your best, and trust that you'll handle things as they come! üåü

title: Mean Messages
story: Spider received mean messages online from someone at school. They felt hurt and embarrassed but weren't sure what to do. They worried that telling someone would make it worse. What should Spider do?
imagePrompt: A spider looking at a screen with mean messages, feeling hurt and worried

choices.text: Tell a trusted adult immediately, save the messages as evidence, block the person, and remember it's not their fault
choices.explanation: Perfect response! Online bullying is serious, and telling an adult is the right thing to do. You didn't do anything wrong, and adults can help stop it!

choices.text: Send mean messages back
choices.explanation: Responding with mean messages usually makes things worse and can get you in trouble too. It's better to tell an adult who can help properly!

choices.text: Ignore it and hope it goes away
choices.explanation: Online bullying usually doesn't stop on its own. Telling a trusted adult is the best way to make it stop and stay safe!

choices.text: Feel like it's their fault for being online
choices.explanation: Being bullied is never your fault! No one deserves mean messages. Telling an adult helps them stop the bullying and keep you safe!

endingMessage: You're brave for speaking up! Online bullying is never okay, and you did the right thing by telling an adult. You deserve to be treated with respect! üõ°Ô∏è

title: Body Image Worries
story: Seal noticed their body looked different from other kids. Some kids were taller, thinner, or looked different in other ways. Seal felt self-conscious and worried about how they looked. What should Seal do?
imagePrompt: A seal looking at themselves in a mirror, feeling self-conscious about their appearance

choices.text: Remember that bodies come in all shapes and sizes, focus on being healthy and strong, talk to trusted adults about concerns, and value themselves for who they are
choices.explanation: Perfect! Everyone's body is different, and that's normal! What matters is being healthy and happy, not looking like someone else. You're wonderful just as you are!

choices.text: Try to change their body to look like others
choices.explanation: Our bodies are unique and wonderful! Trying to change yourself to look like others isn't healthy. Focus on being healthy and happy in your own body!

choices.text: Worry constantly about their appearance
choices.explanation: It's normal to notice differences, but remember - everyone looks different! What matters is being healthy and valuing yourself for who you are, not just how you look!

choices.text: Avoid looking in mirrors completely
choices.explanation: Avoiding mirrors won't help you feel better about yourself. Learning to appreciate your body and focus on health is better than avoiding yourself!

endingMessage: You're beautiful just as you are! Everyone's body is different, and that's wonderful. Focus on being healthy and valuing yourself - you're amazing! üí™

title: Dating Pressure
story: Swan's friends were all talking about having crushes and dating, but Swan wasn't interested in that yet. They felt pressured to like someone or act interested, even though they weren't ready. What should Swan do?
imagePrompt: A swan looking uncomfortable while friends discuss dating and crushes

choices.text: Be honest that they're not interested yet, remember that everyone develops at their own pace, and know it's okay not to be ready
choices.explanation: Perfect! Everyone develops at their own pace, and that's completely normal. It's okay not to be interested in dating yet - there's no rush!

choices.text: Pretend to like someone just to fit in
choices.explanation: Pretending won't make you happy! It's perfectly normal not to be interested yet. Being honest about where you are is better than pretending!

choices.text: Feel like there's something wrong with them
choices.explanation: There's nothing wrong with you! Everyone is different, and some people aren't interested in dating until later. That's completely normal!

choices.text: Avoid friends who talk about dating
choices.explanation: You don't have to avoid friends! It's okay to have different interests. Being honest about not being ready is fine - good friends will understand!

endingMessage: You're perfect just as you are! Everyone develops at their own pace, and there's no rush. It's okay to wait until you feel ready - and you might never feel ready, and that's okay too! üíï

title: Ready to Fly
story: Eagle felt ready for more independence - staying home alone sometimes, walking to friends' houses, making more of their own choices. But parents said they weren't old enough yet. Eagle felt frustrated. What should Eagle do?
imagePrompt: An eagle looking frustrated while parents explain they're not old enough for certain freedoms yet

choices.text: Talk to parents about wanting more responsibility, show they can handle small responsibilities first, and understand that independence comes gradually
choices.explanation: Excellent approach! Showing you can handle small responsibilities first helps parents trust you with more independence. It comes gradually as you prove you're ready!

choices.text: Do things without permission to prove they're ready
choices.explanation: Going behind parents' backs breaks trust and makes them less likely to give you independence! Showing responsibility in small ways is better!

choices.text: Feel frustrated and argue constantly
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel frustrated, but arguing won't help. Showing responsibility in small ways helps parents see you're ready for more independence!

choices.text: Compare themselves to friends who have more freedom
choices.explanation: Comparing to friends won't help - every family has different rules! Focus on showing your parents you're responsible through your actions!

endingMessage: You're growing up! Independence comes gradually as you show responsibility. Keep proving you can handle small things, and more freedom will come! You're doing great! üïäÔ∏è
